intro: Cinna mexicana, commonly known as the Mexican cinnamon or false cinnamon, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and small, clustered white flowers. The plant produces small, red berries that contain seeds, and its foliage is often used in traditional medicine. Cinna mexicana is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for both ecological studies and horticultural cultivation.
